24.text: First in the spotlight tonight is Sarah Jane Bodell,

29.text: She's answering questions on the television series

33.text: John Savage is a salesman from Falkirk.

35.text: His specialist subject, the football manager Jock Stein.

38.text: Next, Wayne Stafford, a retail manager from Oldham and his subject,

46.text: He answers questions on the Suez Crisis.

59.text: Hello and welcome to Mastermind with me, John Humphrys.

63.text: Four more contenders are all set to take to the stage tonight,

67.text: or at least they hope they are all set.

70.text: An awful lot of revision goes into mugging up for the specialist round

73.text: but at least they have some idea of where the questions are coming from.

77.text: In the general knowledge round, they don't have a clue.

80.text: So that can be the real killer.

82.text: They get two minutes each for the first round and then

85.text: two and a half of the second.

86.text: The winner will claim the last place in the semifinals

89.text: and be on course to become the next Mastermind champion.

93.text: So, let's get on with it and ask our first contender to join us, please.

111.text: A Bit Of Fry & Laurie in two minutes, here we go.

114.text: The recurring characters in the first two series

116.text: include a spy called Tony played by Hugh Laurie

119.text: and his boss played by Stephen Fry.

124.text: In a series one sketch set in a restaurant,

126.text: what animal is presented alive as Stephen Fry's

128.text: main course to be prepared at the table?

131.text: During an episode in series two, Fry and Laurie claimed that a company has become

135.text: the show's new sponsor and in one sketch, Laurie's character is

138.text: made to kiss one of their products. What's the company called?

142.text: What do Fry and Laurie wear as a protest against censorship

145.text: in the introduction to episode three of series two

151.text: In the only episode in series four in which there are no guest stars,

154.text: Laurie replaces one guest with a pair of old trousers.

157.text: What does Fry replace the other one with?

159.text:
- Humbrol paint. 
- Yes, a tin of old paint.

161.text: What's the name of the contestant played by Carol MacReady

163.text: in a parody of the game show Countdown in which Fry plays the quizmaster

167.text: and Laurie plays the contestant Simon Sad?

172.text: In the first sketch of the pilot episode,

174.text: Fry and Laurie are under surveillance in an airport.

176.text: What word is repeated three times as the code

182.text: In series one, Hugh Laurie plays a song on the piano

184.text: dressed in a checked shirt and a bandanna.

187.text: The lyrics of the song consist of variations on the name of which country?

192.text: In a series four episode, Laurie has a bandaged head.

194.text: According to a video clip, which Australian actress caused his injury?

201.text: Anne Charleston. In Flowers For Wendy, Laurie's character

204.text: buys some flowers for his wife Wendy's birthday even though he is

207.text: warned by the flower seller they can bring out a what emotion in a person?

212.text: In series two episode six, there's a special tribute to Laurie

215.text: who has been accidentally killed by Fry.

217.text: When Rowan Atkinson speaks about him in the tribute,

220.text: whose name appears on the screen instead of Atkinson's?

224.text: In a sketch in which they sit at either end of a long table,

226.text: Fry repeatedly mishears Laurie's request to pass down what?

231.text: During a series four sketch parodying the film It's A Wonderful Life,

234.text: Fry and Laurie's characters hail a cab. BEEP

240.text: Is correct. No passes, Sarah Jane.

271.text: Jock Stein in two minutes, here we go.

273.text: Stein played for and managed Glasgow Celtic and was the

275.text: first manager of a British side to win the European Cup.

278.text: Which club did Stein leave in March '65 to take over at Celtic?

283.text: Which future Lisbon Lion did Stein sell cheaply to Celtic in 1964

286.text: for a reported fee of £4,000 while he was still manager of Hibernian?

292.text: Stein played for which junior football team of which his father was a committee member?

298.text: Who did Stein marry at the Gilmore Memorial Church

304.text: No, Jeanie McAuley. Who was the Celtic reserve team trainer

307.text: and former team-mate who recommended Stein to fill

310.text: Celtic's short-term need for a centre back in December '51?

314.text: Stein captained Celtic to which trophy in May '53?

317.text: After beating Arsenal and Manchester United,

319.text: they defeated Hibernian 2-0 in the final.

323.text: Whose dismissal as Scottish manager in '65 led to Stein

326.text: acting as caretaker manager of the national side for seven matches?

331.text: Ian McColl. In Stein's first match as Celtic manager in March '65,

334.text: they beat Airdrie 6-0 with John Hughes scoring the first goal.

340.text: It was Bertie Auld. Stein played for Albion Rovers from '42-'50.

345.text: Throughout this time, he worked as a miner in which colliery?

350.text: It was Bothwell. Which fellow manager said to Stein after

353.text: Celtic had won the '67 European Cup final, "John, you're immortal."

358.text: Stein was managing Scotland in a World Cup qualifying match

361.text: when he collapsed and died in September '85 at which ground?

366.text: How much was each member of the Celtic team fined

368.text: following a controversial world club championship play-off

371.text: against Racing Club in Montevideo in November '67

374.text: in which several Celtic players were sent off?

378.text: In 1972, at which club's ground did Stein dive in

381.text: amongst the Celtic supporters to remonstrate with them

384.text: for the sectarian singing of IRA songs?

388.text: During Celtic's 1970 post-season tour of North America,

392.text: Stein famously left the ground during BEEP

394.text: an ill-tempered match against which Italian club?

397.text: It later transpired that he'd flown home.

428.text: Stax Records, here we go. Two minutes.

431.text: Stax Records was founded in Memphis, Tennessee in 1957

434.text: and is renowned for R&B, blues and soul music.

436.text: What single by Booker T And The MG's -

438.text: originally the B-side to their single Behave Yourself -

441.text: reached number one on the R&B charts?

444.text: What was the original name of Stax Records, changed in 1961

447.text: because there was another label of the same name in California?

451.text: What was the name of the former cinema on East McLemore Avenue in Memphis

455.text: that was rented and converted into a recording studio

458.text: and a record shop to become the home of Stax Records?

462.text: The Capitol. The name Stax comes from the surnames of the brother and sister

465.text: who founded the company - S-T is from Jim Stewart. Who is A-X from?

470.text: Which guitarist's unsuccessful recording session at Stax studios

473.text: gave his band's assistant and driver, Otis Redding,

476.text: the opportunity to record two songs in the remaining session time?

480.text: What was the name of the gospel group signed by Stax

482.text: who became one of the biggest R&B acts of the first half of the 1970s?

486.text: Their hits included Respect Yourself and I'll Take You There.

490.text: What was the name of the subsidiary label whose first release in '61

493.text: was an instrumental called Burnt Biscuits?

497.text: Which duo's '66 debut Stax LP Hold On I'm Comin'

500.text: went to number one in the US rhythm and blues album chart?

505.text: Who was the Detroit music producer responsible

507.text: for several hits for Johnnie Taylor and others?

510.text: He was later head of the company's A&R department.

513.text: What was the name of the legendary concert

515.text: held at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum in August '72

519.text: that featured a host of Stax artists

521.text: and became known as the Black Woodstock?

524.text: With which at Atlantic Records executive did Jim Stewart

527.text: agree on a handshake, a record distribution deal

529.text: that resulted in the label losing ownership of all master recordings?

534.text: Which record company acquired the master tapes

540.text: What is the title of Isaac Hayes' four-track album of '69

543.text: which includes an 18-minute version of By The Time I Get To Phoenix

547.text: and 12-minute version of Walk On By?

550.text: Which former Stax in-house songwriter BEEP

554.text: was hired by Fantasy Records in '77 to relaunch the label?

560.text: No passes, Wayne. You've got 12 points.

591.text: The Suez Crisis was prompted by President Nasser of Egypt's

594.text: nationalisation of the Suez Canal in 1956.

596.text: Who was Secretary General of the United Nations during the crisis?

599.text: He worked to find a solution between Nasser

602.text: and the governments of Britain, France and Israel?

605.text: Which city guards the Strait of Tiran and the entrance to the

608.text: Gulf of Aqaba? Its capture by the Israelis

610.text: ended the Egyptian blockade of the Straits?

613.text: The British government hosted a conference in August '56 to discuss

617.text: the international response to the nationalisation.

619.text: In which building was the conference held?

624.text: Lancaster House. Who was the British Prime Minister at the time?

627.text: His wife said of the period, "For the past few weeks,

630.text: "I have felt as if the Suez Canal was flowing through my drawing room."

634.text: What was the name of the field marshal in overall command

637.text: of the Egyptian military forces during the crisis?

640.text: No, Abdel Hakim Amer. Who was the commander of the Israeli 202nd Airborne Brigade

644.text: during the crisis? He later went on to become Prime Minister of Israel.

649.text: What code name was given to the Israeli operation

655.text: Nasser declared that he would fund a building project

658.text: from Suez Canal revenues after America and Britain

660.text: withdrew their financial support in July '56.

665.text: What was the name of the Royal Navy ship that acted as the British command vessel

669.text: for General Stockwell when his land forces reached Port Said?

673.text: What name did Nasser use as a code word in his speech

676.text: announcing the nationalisation of the canal?

678.text: It was the signal to Egyptian troops to seize control of it.

683.text: Britain, France and Israel negotiated a secret agreement

686.text: in October '56 in which Britain and France

688.text: planned to free the Suez Canal zone

690.text: after Israel launched a military attack on Egypt.

693.text: In which suburb of Paris was the agreement made?

696.text: Which Soviet politician sent letters to the British, French and Israeli leaders

703.text: if Allied forces did not withdraw from Egypt?

706.text: On what date in '56 did British and

708.text: French paratroops first land on Egyptian soil?

714.text:
- Aidan, no passes. You have 11 points. 
- Thank you.

729.text: Well, a very close round. Let's have a look at the scores.

732.text: In fourth place, nine points, John Savage.

739.text: Sarah Jane Bodell and Wayne Stafford.

748.text: And it is the general knowledge round now

750.text: and if there's a tie at the end of it, the number of passes

753.text: is taken into account and the person with the fewer passes is the winner.

756.text: And if they're tied on passes as well, there will be a tie-break.

760.text: And the six highest-scoring runners up, incidentally,

763.text: will also be able to claim a place in the semifinals,

768.text: Let's get on with it and ask John to join us again if he would, please.

773.text: ..you start out with nine points, John,

775.text: with your knowledge of Jock Stein.

777.text: You get two and a half minutes for general knowledge, so here we go.

839.text: "O, what a panic's in thy breastie!"

860.text: of its rock strata into three units?

867.text: of York and Lancaster is widely attributed to Sir Walter Scott

890.text: "remark all these roughnesses, pimples, warts, and everything as you see me,

903.text: That Was The Week That Was.

917.text: has its roots in the 19th century

919.text: and was officially founded on 1st January 1935?

928.text: Canary. Who was the first Christian martyr?

930.text: He was stoned to death in Jerusalem in about AD 36

933.text: after being accused of blasphemy? BEEP

937.text: Very good general knowledge round, no passes.

- You've now got, John, 26 points.

1338.text: The name of which Japanese unarmed martial arts discipline

1504.text: Well, it's not all that often that a person who comes last

1507.text: in the specialist round comes first at the end of the contest

1510.text: but that's what has happened tonight.

1512.text: Let's look at all the scores.

1513.text: In fourth place with 19 points, Aidan Loy.

1517.text: In joint second place, 22 points apiece,

1520.text: Sarah Jane Bodell and Wayne Stafford.

1523.text: In first place with 26 points, John Savage.

1538.text: Which means that John is tonight's winner

1540.text: and he claims the last place in the semifinals.

1546.text: Now, if you would like to be a contender in the next series,
